Example 2.3
For A=
[1 2 3
3 2 1
]
∈R2×3, B=


0 2
1 −1
0 1

∈R3×2, we obtain
AB=
[1 2 3
3 2 1
]

0 2
1 −1
0 1

=
[2 3
2 5
]
∈R2×2, (2.15)
BA=


0 2
1 −1
0 1


[1 2 3
3 2 1
]
=


6 4 2
−2 0 2
3 2 1

∈R3×3 . (2.16)
Figure 2.5 Even if
both matrix
multiplications AB
and BAare
deﬁned, the
dimensions of the
results can be
different.
From this example, we can already see that matrix multiplication is not
commutative, i.e., AB̸= BA; see also Figure 2.5 for an illustration.
